title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The whole distance is divided into three stages by two public- houses, one at Olascarnoch, twelve miles from Garve, and another near Fascrinich, or Braemore, about the same distance further on, where a new road from the district of Dundonald and Groinard joins the main one at the top of Loch Broom.*

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: After leaving Irvine a view is obtained, on the left, of the remains of the ancient castle of Dundonald, standing on an elevated position, about two miles distant, and which gives the title of Earl to the family of Cochrane.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: No sooner had the Scottish army crossed the borders, than the Presbyterians, and all revolutionary spirits, crowded to Edinburgh  well armed, and there held secret and seditious meetings,  which were attended by the earls of Dundonald, Crauford, Glencairn, and others.

title: The Scottish cavalier;
author: Grant, James
snippet: In these eastern wars, St. Louis was twice saved from death by the valour of a small band of auxiliary Scots crusaders, commanded by the earls of March and Dunbar, Walter Stewart, lord of Dundonald, and Sir David Lindsay of Glen- esk.

title: The journal of a tour to the Hebrides, with Samuel Johnson, L.L.D. /
author: Boswell, James
snippet: As we passed very near the castle of Dundonald, which was one of the many residences of the kings of Scotland, and in which Robert the Second lived and died.

title: The Diamond Rose: a life of love and duty.
author: Tytler, Sarah
snippet: My grandfather, auld Dundonald, had spoken forhim in vain,—-we were certified that the deathwarrant was to be whipped down from Londonere another stroke could be struck in his savour.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Earls of Glencairn, Crawford, Dundonald, and Tarras, with several otherpersons of consideration, encouraged the rising of the Presbyterians, who, hastilyassuming arms, appeared in different parts of the country, in open opposition tothe government.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Dundonald, and Tarras, with several other personsof consideration, encouraged the rising of the lies.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: died at his castle of Dundonald inKyle, after a short illness, in the seventy-fifth yearof his age, on the lfith April, 13fl0.
